questions.text: When capillary and interstitial hydrostatic pressures are 3 mm of Hg and 0 mm of Hg and colloid oncotic pressure of capillaries and interstitium is 25 mm of Hg and 5 mm of Hg, What is the Net filtration pressure?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 17 mm Hg

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Net Filtration Pressure (NFP) is calculated as the difference between hydrostatic and oncotic pressures in capillaries and interstitium. A negative NFP means net reabsorption into capillaries, preventing edema. ​​
  • ➤ Net Filtration Pressure (NFP) is calculated as the difference between hydrostatic and oncotic pressures in capillaries and interstitium. A negative NFP means net reabsorption into capillaries, preventing edema.

questions.text: In a given arteriolar blood vessel, the pressure is held constant and the radius is decreased. The resultant change in blood flow could also be accomplished by keeping pressure and radius constant and changing which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Increasing viscosity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Poiseuille’s Law states that blood flow (Q) is directly proportional to the fourth power of the vessel radius and inversely proportional to viscosity and vessel length. To decrease flow without changing radius or pressure, increasing viscosity (η) is the best option.

questions.text: MMC (migrating motor complexes) occurs at the rate of ___ and at an interval of_________:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 5 cm/min, 90 min

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Migrating Motor Complex (MMC) occurs in fasting states at intervals of 90 minutes and moves at a rate of approximately 5 cm/min, helping clear the gastrointestinal tract between meals.

questions.text: Which of the following accurately describes the cardiovascular regulation?

options.label: A
options.text: Baroreceptors get activated in hypotension and help increase Blood pressure

options.label: B
options.text: Baroreceptors inhibit the nucleus ambiguous which inhibits the sympathetic system

options.label: C
options.text: Nucleus tractus solitarius activates vagal centres

options.label: D
options.text: Vagus nerve carries afferent fibres from carotid sinus baroreceptors

questions.correct_answer: C. Nucleus tractus solitarius activates vagal centres
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Nucleus tractus solitarius activates vagal centres

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The nucleus tractus solitarius (NTS) plays a central role in cardiovascular regulation by receiving baroreceptor signals and activating vagal centers to reduce blood pressure. Baroreceptors respond to increased BP, not hypotension, and send afferent signals via CN IX (carotid sinus) and CN X (aortic arch).

questions.text: A 53-year-old male is brought to the emergency department with complains of right sided weakness and jargon speech. A CT brain was ordered to rule out haemorrhagic stroke. On neurological examination, there is normal object recognition but loss of comprehension. Which of the following areas is affected?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Superior temporal gyrus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Wernicke’s area, located in the superior temporal gyrus (Brodmann area 22) of the dominant hemisphere, is responsible for language comprehension. A lesion here results in Wernicke’s aphasia, characterized by fluent but meaningless speech (jargon speech) and impaired comprehension, while object recognition remains intact.

questions.text: Identify the sleep wave marked in the EEG during sleep wake cycle?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) REM Sleep

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ REM sleep, also known as paradoxical sleep, is characterized by beta waves on EEG, rapid eye movements (seen on EOG), and muscle atonia (seen on EMG). It is essential for memory consolidation and is the phase where vivid dreaming occurs.

questions.text: A young man met with a motor bike accident and had injury to ileum and jejunum. Therefore the entire ileum and partial jejunum was resected. Which of the following would the patient suffer from?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Vitamin B12 deficiency

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The terminal ileum is the primary site for Vitamin B12 and bile acid absorption. Resection of the ileum leads to Vitamin B12 deficiency, which can cause pernicious anemia and neurological symptoms.

questions.text: Detachment of myosin head from actin is caused by:

options.label: B
options.text: Attachment of ATP to the head

options.label: C
options.text: Binding of ADP and Pi to the head

questions.correct_answer: B. Attachment of ATP to the head
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Attachment of ATP to the head

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ ATP binding to myosin causes its detachment from actin, leading to muscle relaxation. ATP hydrolysis re-energizes myosin, and the release of Pi provides energy for the power stroke during contraction.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man with a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus presents to the clinic for a routine check-up. His medications include an ACE inhibitor and a diuretic which can affect the tubulo-glomerular feedback. Which one of the following is primarily regulated by the tubulo-glomerular feedback mechanism?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) GFR

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tubuloglomerular feedback (TGF) is an autoregulatory mechanism that primarily regulates GFR by adjusting afferent and efferent arteriole resistance in response to NaCl concentration changes at the macula densa.

questions.text: In 50-year-old patient with respiratory distress, FEV1 = 1.5litre and FVC =3.0 litres. The type of disease he is suffering from:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Bronchitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A decreased FEV1/FVC ratio (<70%) is a hallmark of obstructive lung diseases like bronchitis, whereas restrictive lung diseases (e.g., fibrosis, tuberculosis) show a normal or increased FEV1/FVC ratio (≥80%).

questions.text: If a substances appears in the renal artery but not in the renal vein:

options.label: A
options.text: Its clearance is equal to the glomerular filtration rate.

options.label: B
options.text: It must be reabsorbed by the kidney

options.label: C
options.text: Its urinary concentration must be higher than its plasma concentration

options.label: D
options.text: Its clearance is equal to the renal plasma flow

questions.correct_answer: D. Its clearance is equal to the renal plasma flow
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Its clearance is equal to the renal plasma flow

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A substance that appears in the renal artery but not in the renal vein must be completely excreted by the kidney, meaning its clearance equals the renal plasma flow (RPF). Para-Aminohippuric Acid (PAH) is the classic example of such a substance.

questions.text: All are true about Decerebrate posture except:

options.label: A
options.text: Extension of both upper and lower extremity

options.label: B
options.text: Flexion of upper extremity and extension of lower extremity

options.label: D
options.text: Reticulo spinal tract is also involved.

questions.correct_answer: B. Flexion of upper extremity and extension of lower extremity
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Flexion of upper extremity and extension of lower extremity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Decerebrate posture is characterized by extension of both upper and lower extremities due to brainstem damage below the red nucleus, leading to loss of rubrospinal tract function and dominance of the pontine reticulospinal tract.

questions.text: The graph below represents the relationship of chest, lung and both together w.r.t. the transmural pressure:

options.label: A
options.text: A= Curve for chest wall; B= Curve for Lung; X= Residual Volume

options.label: B
options.text: A= Curve for Lung; B= Curve for Chest wall; X= Residual Volume

options.label: C
options.text: A= Curve for chest wall; B= Curve for Lung; X= Functional Residual Capacity

options.label: D
options.text: A= Curve for Lung; B= Curve for Chest wall; X= Functional Residual Capacity

questions.correct_answer: C. A= Curve for chest wall; B= Curve for Lung; X= Functional Residual Capacity
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) A= Curve for chest wall; B= Curve for Lung; X= Functional Residual Capacity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) is the lung volume at which the inward elastic recoil of the lung is balanced by the outward recoil of the chest wall, creating a state of equilibrium with no active muscular effort.

questions.text: Correct sequence after ‘a' wave of JVP- Rapid ejection R wave 1st Heart Sound T wave in ECG Select the correct answer using the code below:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 2 → 3 → 1 → 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ After the ‘a’ wave (atrial contraction), the sequence of cardiac events follows: R wave (ventricular depolarization) → S1 (AV valve closure) → Rapid ejection → T wave (ventricular repolarization). Electrical events precede mechanical events.

questions.text: The following diagram shows the depth of respiration of a 45-year-old man who suffered a head injury in an automobile accident. This “crescendodecrescendo” pattern of breathing is called which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Cheyne-Stokes breathing

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cheyne-Stokes breathing is a crescendo-decrescendo breathing pattern followed by apnea, seen in conditions like heart failure, high altitude, and brain injuries. It is caused by delayed feedback of CO₂ regulation in the respiratory centers.

questions.text: All of the following are true about myocardium except:

options.label: A
options.text: Increase Sympathetic activity causes positive ionotropic and negative lusitropic effect

options.label: B
options.text: Increase Sympathetic activity causes positive ionotropic and positive lusitropic effect

options.label: C
options.text: Lusitropic effect is mediated by cAMP dependent pathway

options.label: D
options.text: Increase Ca2+ uptake from ECF to cytoplasm decreases lucitropy in the absence of sympathetic stimulation

questions.correct_answer: A. Increase Sympathetic activity causes positive ionotropic and negative lusitropic effect
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Increase Sympathetic activity causes positive ionotropic and negative lusitropic effect

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sympathetic stimulation enhances both inotropic (force of contraction) and lusitropic (relaxation) effects in the myocardium via β1-receptors, cAMP, and PKA-mediated phosphorylation of phospholamban, leading to increased SERCA activity.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman with hematemesis has heart- burn and stomach pain. An endoscopy shows inflammation involving the gastric body and antrum as well as a small gastric ulcer. Biopsies were positive for H. pylori. H. pylori damages the gastric mucosa primarily by increasing mucosal levels of which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Ammonium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ H. pylori damages the gastric mucosa primarily by producing urease, which breaks down urea into ammonium, increasing mucosal pH and leading to excessive acid secretion, mucosal injury, and ulcer formation.

questions.text: All of the following are True in SIADH except:

options.label: B
options.text: Urine Na+ concentration < 20 mmol/L with normal salt intake

questions.correct_answer: B. Urine Na+ concentration < 20 mmol/L with normal salt intake
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Urine Na+ concentration < 20 mmol/L with normal salt intake

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ SIADH is characterized by low plasma osmolality (<275 mOsm/L), high urine osmolality (>100 mOsm/L), and increased natriuresis (>20 mmol/L) despite normal salt intake due to ANP-mediated sodium excretion.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman is suffering from common cold visited the hospital with complain of vomiting since three days and extreme weakness. Her examination and lab findings are as: BP - 90/60mmHg Pulse - 110/ min RR - 10 /min Blood pH - 7.6 Plasma bicarbonate - 30mEq/L, PCO2 - 45mmHg What should be patient’s current acid -base status and hormone involved:

options.label: B
options.text: Metabolic alkalosis, aldosterone and angiotensin II

options.label: C
options.text: Respiratory acidosis, aldosterone and angiotensin II

questions.correct_answer: B. Metabolic alkalosis, aldosterone and angiotensin II
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Metabolic alkalosis, aldosterone and angiotensin II

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Prolonged vomiting leads to metabolic alkalosis due to the loss of HCl, which triggers hypovolemia and activation of the Renin-Angiotensin-Aldosterone System (RAAS), leading to sodium and water retention. ANP is not activated in hypovolemia.

questions.text: Physiologists divided the nerve fibers into specific groups based on the myelination and thickness of nerve fibers. Select the incorrect characteristic of nerve fibers in different groups:

options.label: A
options.text: Type C fibers are small unmyelinated nerve fibers that conduct impulses at low velocities.

options.label: B
options.text: Type A fibers are the typically large and medium-sized myelinated fibers of spinal nerves.

options.label: C
options.text: Type B fibers are further subdivided into α, β, and δ fibers.

options.label: D
options.text: Subset of type A fibers has conduction velocity between 70-120 m/s.

questions.correct_answer: C. Type B fibers are further subdivided into α, β, and δ fibers.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Type B fibers are further subdivided into α, β, and δ fibers.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Type A fibers are large, myelinated, and fast-conducting, whereas Type C fibers are small, unmyelinated, and slow-conducting. Type B fibers are autonomic preganglionic fibers and are NOT subdivided into α, β, and δ subtypes (which only apply to Type A fibers).

questions.text: A medical student have given a topic to present in class. The topic given to you was excitation-contraction coupling. It is a process in which muscle cells are stimulated to contract and it is followed by muscle cell relaxation. It involves the following events. Action potential Calcium release into the cytoplasm Cross-bridge cycling Cytoplasmic calcium removal Depolarization of T tubules Which of the following options lists the correct sequence of events for excitation-contraction coupling in skeletal muscle tissue?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1, 5, 2, 3, 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Excitation-contraction coupling involves action potential propagation along the sarcolemma, depolarization of T-tubules, calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum via ryanodine receptors, cross-bridge cycling for muscle contraction, and eventual calcium reuptake into the sarcoplasmic reticulum for relaxation.

questions.text: All of the following are components responsible for the counter current mechanism in the kidney except:

options.label: A
options.text: Sodium outflow in thick ascending limb

options.label: B
options.text: Water outflow in thin descending limb

options.label: C
options.text: Sodium outflow in thin ascending limb

options.label: D
options.text: Flow of tubular fluid from PCT to DCT

questions.correct_answer: D. Flow of tubular fluid from PCT to DCT
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Flow of tubular fluid from PCT to DCT

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The counter-current mechanism in the kidney, primarily involving the Loop of Henle and vasa recta, helps concentrate urine by creating a medullary osmotic gradient. The thick ascending limb actively pumps Na⁺ out, the thin descending limb allows water reabsorption, and the thin ascending limb allows passive sodium outflow. The PCT and DCT are not part of this system.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man met with a bike accident and handle of bike hit him badly that when he was brought to the hospital. Doctors find out that there is puncture in parietal pleura membrane. True about this condition is:

options.label: A
options.text: Unopposed inward recoil will be there.

options.label: B
options.text: Intra thorax pressure will be zero

options.label: D
options.text: Both A and B are true.

questions.correct_answer: D. Both A and B are true.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Both A and B are true.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pneumothorax occurs when the pleural space is opened to the atmosphere, causing intrapleural pressure to equalize with atmospheric pressure (0 mmHg). This eliminates the negative pressure that keeps the lung expanded, leading to lung collapse due to unopposed elastic recoil.

questions.text: A patient with parathyroid deficiency 10 days after inadvertent damage to the parathyroid glands during thyroid surgery would probably have:

options.label: A
options.text: Low plasma phosphate and Ca2+ levels and tetanus.

options.label: B
options.text: Low plasma Ca2+ level, increased muscular excitability and spasm of the muscles.

options.label: C
options.text: High plasma phosphate and Ca2+ levels and bone demineralization.

options.label: D
options.text: Increased muscular excitability, a high plasma Ca2+ level, and bone demineralization

questions.correct_answer: B. Low plasma Ca2+ level, increased muscular excitability and spasm of the muscles.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Low plasma Ca2+ level, increased muscular excitability and spasm of the muscles.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hypoparathyroidism leads to hypocalcemia and hyperphosphatemia. Low calcium increases neuromuscular excitability, causing symptoms like Trousseau’s and Chvostek’s signs, muscle spasms, and tetany.

questions.text: 43-year-old female came for the routine checkup, on investigation found out to be overweight. She was asymptomatic so just advised life style modification and decrease carbohydrate intake. Which curve in adjacent graph shows its transport of glucose across the enterocyte membrane?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) B

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glucose transport across enterocytes occurs via facilitated diffusion (GLUT-2) and sodium-dependent active transport (SGLT-1). Facilitated diffusion follows a saturable kinetics pattern (Vmax), as shown in Curve B.

questions.text: Which of the following are secreted from the parietal cells of the stomach? Mucous Hydrochloric acid Gastrin Intrinsic factor
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 2, 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Parietal cells secrete hydrochloric acid (HCl) and intrinsic factor (IF), which are essential for digestion and vitamin B12 absorption, respectively. Gastrin is secreted by G-cells, while mucous is secreted by mucous cells.

questions.text: In a child presenting with short stature, GH levels were found to be high but IGF-1 levels are low. Likely abnormality?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) GH receptor defect

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ GH receptor defects (Laron syndrome) result in high GH levels but low IGF-1 levels, leading to growth failure. This is due to the inability of GH to act on the liver and stimulate IGF-1 production.

questions.text: In a 30-year-old healthy male, the different body fluid compartments were measured. Which of the following can be used to measure his interstitial fluid volume?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Thiosulfate & Evan’s Blue

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Interstitial Fluid Volume (IFV) is calculated as ECF - Plasma Volume. Thiosulfate is used to measure ECF, and Evan’s Blue is used to measure Plasma Volume.

questions.text: Difference in trajectory between inspiratory loop and the expiratory loop in the curve is due to:

options.label: A
options.text: Difference in alveolar pressure during inspiration and expiration

options.label: B
options.text: Difference in concentration of surfactant during inspiration and expiration

options.label: C
options.text: Difference in airway resistance during inspiration and expiration

options.label: D
options.text: Inspiration is active and expiration is passive

questions.correct_answer: B. Difference in concentration of surfactant during inspiration and expiration
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Difference in concentration of surfactant during inspiration and expiration

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hysteresis in lung compliance occurs due to differences in surfactant concentration between inspiration and expiration. During inspiration, surfactant is spread out, reducing compliance, while during expiration, surfactant is concentrated, increasing compliance.

questions.text: X, Y, Z are the three ions permeable. X =-50 and Y =-30. If at resting membrane potential (RMP), when there is no net electro genic transfer, what is the value of Z?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) +80

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When multiple ions contribute to the resting membrane potential, their equilibrium potentials must sum to zero if there is no net electrogenic transfer. The equilibrium potential of an unknown ion can be determined using algebraic summation.

questions.text: Efferent arteriolar constriction causes all of the following except:

options.label: C
options.text: Increases oncotic pressure in peritubular capillaries

options.label: D
options.text: Increases hydrostatic pressure in glomerular capillaries

questions.correct_answer: C. Increases oncotic pressure in peritubular capillaries
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Increases oncotic pressure in peritubular capillaries

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Efferent arteriolar constriction initially increases glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure, raising GFR. However, excessive constriction reduces GFR due to increased oncotic pressure. Renal blood flow always decreases.

questions.text: A professor discusses the case of a 28-year-old woman experiencing episodic muscle weakness triggered by changes in potassium levels. The professor uses this case to explore the underlying mechanisms of positive feedback mechanism. Which component amongst the given scenario explains the phenomenon?

options.label: A
options.text: The Shell body temperature is increased after activation of thermoregulatory mechanisms such as shivering.

options.label: B
options.text: The core body temperature is maintained even if the environmental temperature is low.

options.label: C
options.text: Voltage-gated sodium channels open in response to initial depolarization, further depolarizing the membrane.

options.label: D
options.text: The heart rate increases just before starting an exercise due to psychic stimuli

questions.correct_answer: C. Voltage-gated sodium channels open in response to initial depolarization, further depolarizing the membrane.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Voltage-gated sodium channels open in response to initial depolarization, further depolarizing the membrane.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Positive feedback mechanisms amplify an initial change instead of counteracting it. A prime example is the Hodgkin cycle, where voltage-gated sodium channels open in response to depolarization, causing further depolarization until inactivation mechanisms intervene.

questions.text: In a patient undergoing cancer treatment, which protein associated with Microtubule Organizing Centres (MTOCs) becomes a key target due to its crucial role in cell division, making it a promising target for chemotherapy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Tubulin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tubulin is a key component of microtubules and MTOCs, making it a prime target for chemotherapy drugs that disrupt mitotic spindle formation, thereby inhibiting cancer cell division.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male athlete presents to the clinic with muscle cramps and weakness after intense training sessions. Investigations are focused on assessing his muscle excitation-contraction coupling mechanism. Which of the following are primarily associated with the L tubules and play a crucial role in the initiation of muscle contraction?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Ryanodine receptors

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ryanodine receptors (RyR) on the sarcoplasmic reticulum are the primary channels responsible for releasing calcium ions, which trigger muscle contraction in the excitation-contraction coupling process.

questions.text: A guinea-pig is dissected and a portion of its intestine is fixed in the modified Dales chamber to study the effects of some drugs on intestinal contractility. A substance X was infused in the broth following which the graph comes out as depicted. Substance X most closely resembles which of these substances?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Epinephrine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Epinephrine inhibits gastrointestinal smooth muscle contraction by activating β2-adrenergic receptors, leading to decreased tension and relaxation of intestinal muscles.

questions.text: The characteristic of a water-insoluble substance most important in governing its diffusibility through a cell membrane is its:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Lipid solubility

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lipid solubility is the most important factor determining the diffusibility of a water-insoluble substance across a cell membrane, as it governs its ability to pass through the lipid bilayer.

questions.text: Weber–Fechner law is related to:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Intensity of stimulus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Weber–Fechner Law states that the perceived intensity of a stimulus is proportional to the logarithm of its actual intensity, meaning smaller increases in weak stimuli are more noticeable than the same increase in strong stimuli.

questions.text: Calculate the ejection fraction from the given diagram?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 50%

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ejection Fraction (EF) is a key parameter in cardiac function assessment, calculated as (SV/EDV) × 100. A normal EF is typically >55%. In heart failure with reduced EF (HFrEF), EF is <40%.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department with complaints of sudden dizziness, nausea, and a drop in blood pressure after receiving an injection for a certain medical condition. On examination, his heart rate is found to be significantly lower than usual, leading towards the Bezold-Jarisch reflex. Which of the following is responsible for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Serotonin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Bezold-Jarisch Reflex is a paradoxical cardiovascular reflex caused by cardiac chemoreceptor activation (by serotonin, veratridine, or capsaicin), leading to bradycardia, hypotension, and vasodilation via vagal activation.
  • ➤ The Bezold-Jarisch Reflex is a paradoxical cardiovascular reflex caused by cardiac chemoreceptor activation (by serotonin, veratridine, or capsaicin), leading to bradycardia, hypotension, and vasodilation via vagal activation.

questions.text: How an electrical synapse is different from a chemical synapse?

options.label: A
options.text: No cytoplasmic continuity between presynaptic and post synaptic space in electric synapses.

options.label: B
options.text: Direction of impulse is unidirectional in electric synapses.

options.label: C
options.text: Connexons are present in electrical synapse

options.label: D
options.text: Electrical synapse has more latent period than chemical synapse

questions.correct_answer: C. Connexons are present in electrical synapse
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Connexons are present in electrical synapse

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Electrical synapses allow fast, bidirectional impulse conduction via connexons (gap junctions) and have minimal synaptic delay, unlike chemical synapses which rely on neurotransmitter release.

questions.text: A 75-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease is undergoing a routine echocardiogram that shows a normal aortic pressure waveform and the timing of coronary blood flow during the cardiac cycle. At which point on the aortic pressure waveform diagram provided is the coronary blood flow is the greatest?

options.label: A
options.text: Point B, when the aortic valve is open and the blood is being ejected into the aorta.

options.label: B
options.text: Point C, at the peak of systolic pressure within the aorta.

options.label: C
options.text: Point D, during the closing of the aortic valve.

options.label: D
options.text: Point E, in the phase of isovolumic relaxation.

questions.correct_answer: D. Point E, in the phase of isovolumic relaxation.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Point E, in the phase of isovolumic relaxation.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Coronary blood flow is highest during diastole, particularly during isovolumic relaxation, as the myocardium relaxes and the compressed coronary arteries open, allowing maximal perfusion.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man is breathing quietly. He then inhales as much air as possible and exhales as much air as he can, producing the spirogram shown in the previous figure. What is his inspiratory capacity (in liters)?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 3.0

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Inspiratory Capacity (IC) is the sum of Tidal Volume (TV) and Inspiratory Reserve Volume (IRV) and represents the maximum amount of air that can be inhaled after a normal exhalation. It is measured from the resting expiratory level to the peak of maximum inspiration.

questions.text: In a discussion about the factors affecting oxygen delivery to tissues, the variations in the oxygen dissociation curve are being reviewed. Which of the following conditions regarding these variations is incorrectly matched. All the following conditions regarding the variations in the oxygen dissociation curve are correctly matched, except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Increased pCO2 – left shift

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An increase in pCO₂, H⁺ (decreased pH), temperature, or 2,3-BPG leads to a right shift in the oxygen dissociation curve, enhancing oxygen delivery to tissues (Bohr Effect). Conversely, decreased pCO₂, H⁺, temperature, or 2,3-BPG causes a left shift, increasing hemoglobin’s affinity for oxygen.

questions.text: In a respiratory clinic, a 45-year-old non-smoker presents with a 6-month history of progressive dyspnea and a nonproductive cough. Physical examination reveals digital clubbing and fine basilar inspiratory crackles. The resulting loop resembles the image provided. Given the patient's symptoms and the flow-volume loop findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis (IPF) is a restrictive lung disease characterized by progressive dyspnea, fine inspiratory crackles, and digital clubbing. Pulmonary function tests show a restrictive pattern with reduced TLC and FVC, and the flow-volume loop appears smaller but maintains a normal shape.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient is experiencing difficulty in consolidating short-term memories into long-term memories, leading to recurrent forgetfulness. The clinician evaluates the patient's neurological function, focusing on structures crucial for memory conversion. In a patient with difficulty in storage of long-term memories after conversion from short term memories, which brain structure plays a crucial role in this process?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Neocortex

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Long-term memory storage primarily occurs in the neocortex, while the hippocampus is responsible for converting short-term memories into long-term ones. Damage to the neocortex can impair long-term memory storage without affecting initial memory formation.

questions.text: A patient with a kidney-related concern is undergoing an evaluation. The healthcare provider discusses the characteristics and functions of juxtamedullary nephrons, including their role in urine concentration and the unique features that distinguish them from cortical nephrons. Which of the following is true about the juxtamedullary nephrons? Vasa recta well developed Short loop of Henle 15% of nephrons Thick and thin ascending loops
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1, 3, 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Juxtamedullary nephrons comprise about 15% of all nephrons and play a crucial role in urine concentration. They have a well-developed vasa recta, a long loop of Henle that extends deep into the medulla, and both thick and thin ascending limbs to aid in countercurrent multiplication and water reabsorption.

questions.text: A nephrologist is explaining to medical students the concept of renal clearance and how different substances are handled by the nephron. Using the graph provided, she asks them to match substances with their typical clearance patterns. Identify the correctly matched pair of substances with their renal clearance from the graph:

options.label: A
options.text: A - Glucose, B - PAH, C - Bicarbonate, D - Inulin

options.label: B
options.text: A - Bicarbonate, B - Glucose, C Inulin -, D – PAH

options.label: C
options.text: A - PAH, B - Inulin, C - Glucose, D - Bicarbonate

options.label: D
options.text: A - Glucose, B - Bicarbonate, C - Inulin, D - PAH

questions.correct_answer: D. A - Glucose, B - Bicarbonate, C - Inulin, D - PAH
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) A - Glucose, B - Bicarbonate, C - Inulin, D – PAH

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glucose is completely reabsorbed in the proximal tubule, bicarbonate is mostly reabsorbed but can be lost in small amounts, inulin is freely filtered but not reabsorbed or secreted (used to measure GFR), and PAH is both filtered and secreted, making it a marker for renal plasma flow.

questions.text: A medical student is studying thyroid physiology and comes across the term 'Wolf-Chaikoff effect.' She is curious about the mechanism underlying this phenomenon. Which of the following best explains the Wolf-Chaikoff effect?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Excessive iodine intake

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Wolff-Chaikoff effect describes the transient inhibition of thyroid hormone synthesis due to excessive iodine intake. This occurs due to decreased iodination of tyrosine residues (MIT and DIT) in thyroglobulin, mediated by the suppression of thyroid peroxidase (TPO).

questions.text: In response to an increase in GFR, the proximal tubule and the loop of Henle demonstrate an increase in the rate of Na+ reabsorption. This phenomenon is called?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Glomerulo tubular balance

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glomerulo tubular balance ensures that the proximal tubule reabsorbs a constant fraction of Na⁺ and water despite changes in GFR. This prevents excessive sodium loss or retention, contributing to renal homeostasis.

questions.text: Which one of the following clinical disorder specifically arises due to the defective functioning of aquaporins, notably AQP2, crucial for water reabsorption in the kidney tubules, which disrupts the kidney's ability to concentrate urine, resulting in a distinctive pattern of excessive urine output, thirst, and potential dehydration despite adequate fluid intake:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Nephrogenic DI

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nephrogenic Diabetes Insipidus (DI) results from defective AQP2 function, leading to impaired water reabsorption, polyuria, polydipsia, and dehydration. Unlike central DI, nephrogenic DI does not respond to ADH treatment.

questions.text: During starvation, graph of three substances are plotted as below. The scale for A and B is on the left and the scale for C is on the right. Which of the substances are represented by the curve A?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) RT3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ During starvation, the body conserves energy by decreasing T3 levels and increasing RT3 levels. Reverse T3 (RT3) is an inactive thyroid hormone that rises significantly in fasting states to suppress metabolic rate.

questions.text: Which one of the following statement accurately describes the a neurological phenomenon commonly observed in motor control and pivotal in maintaining appropriate muscle tension, involves a specific neuronal pathway with interneuronal processing between sensory and motor neurons, regulating muscle contraction by modulating motor neuron activity based on Golgi tendon organ input:

options.label: A
options.text: Occurs when IA spindle afferents are inhibited.

options.label: B
options.text: Is a monosynaptic reflex initiated by activation of the Golgi tendon organ.

options.label: C
options.text: Is a disynaptic reflex with a single interneuron inserted between the afferent and efferent limbs.

options.label: D
options.text: Uses type II afferent fibers from the Golgi tendon organ

questions.correct_answer: C. Is a disynaptic reflex with a single interneuron inserted between the afferent and efferent limbs.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Is a disynaptic reflex with a single interneuron inserted between the afferent and efferent limbs.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Golgi tendon reflex (inverse stretch reflex) is a disynaptic reflex that prevents excessive muscle tension. It involves the Golgi tendon organ (GTO), which sends signals via Ib afferents to an inhibitory interneuron, leading to muscle relaxation.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient presents with symptoms of excessive urination, extreme thirst, and unexplained weight loss over the past few months. Laboratory investigations reveal hyperglycemia and ketonuria. During the investigation of signaling pathways involved in various hormones, Which hormone, in this case of the patient's symptoms suggesting diabetes mellitus, differs from the others by not utilizing cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) as its second messenger system in intracellular signaling pathways?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Prolactin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Prolactin differs from other hormones like ACTH, Dopamine, and Glucagon because it does not use the cAMP second messenger system. Instead, Prolactin signals through the JAK-STAT pathway, which is characteristic of cytokine receptor signaling.
  • ➤ the

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient experiencing irregular menstrual cycles and seeking guidance from her healthcare provider. During the healthcare team explores factors influencing reproductive hormone regulation. Which of the following have a role in controlling the secretion of Prolactin?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Dopamine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dopamine is the primary inhibitory regulator of prolactin secretion. A decrease in dopamine (due to pituitary stalk damage, dopamine antagonists, or hypothalamic dysfunction) leads to increased prolactin levels, which can cause hyperprolactinemia and associated symptoms like menstrual irregularities and galactorrhea.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient undergoing evaluation for a suspected catecholamine-secreting tumor The healthcare team, into a comprehensive discussion on the principal metabolite resulting from norepinephrine metabolism and subsequently excreted in urine and the clinical implications of measuring this metabolite in the context of diagnosing and managing catecholamine-secreting tumors. The metabolite is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Vanillyl Mandelic Acid (VMA)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vanillyl-Mandelic Acid (VMA) is the principal urinary metabolite of norepinephrine metabolism and is a key diagnostic marker for catecholamine-secreting tumors like pheochromocytoma. Measuring urinary VMA helps in confirming excessive catecholamine production.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with a history of osteoporosis is undergoing a comprehensive evaluation of calcium metabolism. Understanding the dynamics of the active form of calcium can help in tailoring interventions to address the patient's osteoporosis and prevent further bone loss, considering both pharmacological and lifestyle-based approaches. The active form of calcium in body is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Ionized calcium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ionized calcium is the biologically active form of calcium in the body and plays a crucial role in neuromuscular function, blood clotting, and bone metabolism. It is regulated by PTH, vitamin D, and calcitonin to maintain calcium homeostasis.

questions.text: The force of muscle contraction can be increased by all except:

options.label: A
options.text: Increasing the frequency of activation of motor units.

options.label: B
options.text: Increasing the number of motor units activated.

options.label: C
options.text: Increasing the strength of stimuli from maximal to supramaximal.

options.label: D
options.text: Increasing the resting length of the muscle.

questions.correct_answer: C. Increasing the strength of stimuli from maximal to supramaximal.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Increasing the strength of stimuli from maximal to supramaximal.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Muscle contraction force can be increased by motor unit recruitment, higher activation frequency, and optimal muscle length . However, increasing stimulus beyond maximal does not further increase force due to the all-or-none law .
  • ➤ motor unit recruitment, higher activation frequency, and optimal muscle length
  • ➤ increasing stimulus beyond maximal does not further increase force due to the all-or-none law

questions.text: Assume that excess blood is transfused into a patient whose arterial baroreceptors are non-functional and whose blood pressure increases from 100 to 150 mm Hg. Then, assume that the same volume of blood is infused into the same patient under conditions in which his arterial baroreceptors are functioning normally, and blood pressure increases from 100 to 125 mm Hg. What is the approximate feedback "gain" of the arterial baroreceptors in this patient when they are functioning normally?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) -1.0

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Baroreceptors function as negative feedback regulators of blood pressure. Their feedback gain is calculated as correction divided by error left , and it is always negative , indicating that they work to counteract deviations in blood pressure.
  • ➤ negative feedback regulators
  • ➤ feedback gain
  • ➤ correction divided by error left
  • ➤ negative

questions.text: A 28-year-old man was seen by neurologist because he had experienced prolonged episodes of tingling and numbness in his right arm. He underwent a neurologic exam to evaluate his sensory nervous system. Which of the following cutaneous mechanoreceptors is correctly paired with the type of stimulus to which it is most apt to respond?
questions.correct_answer: A. Pacinian corpuscle and rapid vibration
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pacinian corpuscle and rapid vibration

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pacinian corpuscles are rapidly adapting mechanoreceptors that respond to high-frequency vibrations and deep pressure , making them essential for detecting dynamic mechanical changes in the environment.
  • ➤ rapidly adapting mechanoreceptors
  • ➤ high-frequency vibrations and deep pressure

questions.text: A 40-year-old man loses his right hand in a farm accident. Four years later, he has episodes, of severe pain in the missing hand (phantom limb pain). A detailed PET scan study of his cerebral cortex might be expected to show:

options.label: A
options.text: Expansion of the right-hand area in his right primary somatosensory cortex.

options.label: B
options.text: Expansion of the right hand area in as left primary somatosensory cortex

options.label: C
options.text: Projection of fibers from neighbouring sensory areas into the right-hand area of his right primary somatosensory cortex.

options.label: D
options.text: Projection of fibers from neighbouring sensory areas into the right-hand area of his left primary somatosensory cortex.

questions.correct_answer: D. Projection of fibers from neighbouring sensory areas into the right-hand area of his left primary somatosensory cortex.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Projection of fibers from neighbouring sensory areas into the right-hand area of his left primary somatosensory cortex.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Phantom limb pain occurs due to cortical remapping , where the neighboring sensory areas project into the deafferented cortical region . In this case, fibers from adjacent sensory areas (e.g., face or upper arm) project into the right-hand area of the left primary somatosensory cortex .
  • ➤ cortical remapping
  • ➤ neighboring sensory areas project into the deafferented cortical region
  • ➤ right-hand area of the left primary somatosensory cortex

questions.text: Polyphagia in diabetes is mainly due to:

options.label: A
options.text: Decreased glucose utilization in most of the tissues of the body

options.label: B
options.text: Decreased glucose uptake by whole brain

options.label: C
options.text: Decreased glucose utilization by entire hypothalamus nuclei

options.label: D
options.text: Decreased glucose utilization of VMH causing less VMI activity.

questions.correct_answer: D. Decreased glucose utilization of VMH causing less VMI activity.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Decreased glucose utilization of VMH causing less VMI activity.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Polyphagia in diabetes is caused by decreased glucose utilization in the ventromedial hypothalamus (VMH), leading to reduced satiety signals . This is due to impaired insulin-dependent glucose uptake , which results in the brain perceiving a state of starvation despite high blood glucose levels .
  • ➤ decreased glucose utilization in the ventromedial hypothalamus (VMH), leading to reduced satiety signals
  • ➤ insulin-dependent glucose uptake
  • ➤ brain perceiving a state of starvation despite high blood glucose levels

questions.text: Which of the following hormone is reported to promote maturation of hypothalamic gonadal axis during puberty?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Leptin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Leptin, secreted by adipose tissue , plays a key role in triggering puberty by stimulating GnRH release , thereby promoting the maturation of the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis .
  • ➤ adipose tissue
  • ➤ triggering puberty
  • ➤ GnRH release
  • ➤ hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis

questions.text: The oxygen taken up by the lungs is 200ml per minute. Oxygen concentration in samples taken from systemic and pulmonary artery is 0.2mL/mL and 0.16ml/mL respectively. What is the cardiac output?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 5.0 L/min

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cardiac output can be calculated using Fick’s Principle , which states that CO = Oxygen consumption / (Arterial O₂ content - Venous O₂ content) . In this case, the CO is 5.0 L/min , which represents the normal resting cardiac output in an adult.
  • ➤ Fick’s Principle
  • ➤ CO = Oxygen consumption / (Arterial O₂ content - Venous O₂ content)
  • ➤ CO is 5.0 L/min

questions.text: Pulmonary compliance:

options.label: B
options.text: Is defined as the change in pressure per unit change in volume.

options.label: C
options.text: Compliance is slightly greater when measured during deflation than when measured during inflation

questions.correct_answer: C. Compliance is slightly greater when measured during deflation than when measured during inflation
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Compliance is slightly greater when measured during deflation than when measured during inflation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pulmonary compliance is higher during deflation (expiration) than inflation (inspiration) due to hysteresis . It is increased in emphysema due to loss of elastic recoil and decreased in pulmonary fibrosis due to lung stiffening.
  • ➤ higher during deflation (expiration) than inflation (inspiration)
  • ➤ hysteresis
  • ➤ increased in emphysema
  • ➤ decreased in pulmonary fibrosis

questions.text: In regional ventilation and perfusion of the lung, which of the following is correct:

options.label: A
options.text: Upper regions of the lung ventilate better than the lower regions

options.label: B
options.text: When supine the apical and basal ventilation is equal

options.label: C
options.text: V/Q ratio increases down the lung

options.label: D
options.text: The highest alveolar PO 2 , is at the base of the lung.

questions.correct_answer: B. When supine the apical and basal ventilation is equal
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) When supine the apical and basal ventilation is equal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the supine position , the effect of gravity on ventilation distribution is minimized , leading to equal ventilation per unit area at both the apex and the base of the lung .
  • ➤ supine position
  • ➤ ventilation distribution is minimized
  • ➤ equal ventilation per unit area at both the apex and the base of the lung

questions.text: Which one of the following definitions is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: The respiratory minute volume equals the amount of air inspired per minute.

options.label: B
options.text: Residual volume is the air left in the lungs after a maximal expiratory effort

options.label: C
options.text: Vital capacity is the maximal amount of air that can be expired after a normal inspiration

options.label: D
options.text: Physiological dead space is the amount of air not equilibrating with blood.

questions.correct_answer: C. Vital capacity is the maximal amount of air that can be expired after a normal inspiration
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Vital capacity is the maximal amount of air that can be expired after a normal inspiration.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vital capacity (VC) is the maximum volume of air exhaled after a forceful inspiration. The incorrect definition stated that it is after a normal inspiration , which is not true.
  • ➤ Vital capacity (VC) is the maximum volume of air exhaled after a forceful inspiration.
  • ➤ a normal inspiration

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to emergency with severe sudden-onset heart palpitations. The patient reports symptoms of chest pain, fatigue, and dizziness. Upon examination, his heart rate is 165/min and regular. His blood pressure is 106/74 mmHg. A gentle massage below the level of the left mandible elicits an immediate improvement in the patient, as his heart rate returns to 60/min. What was the mechanism of action of this manoeuvre?

options.label: A
options.text: Increasing the refractory period in ventricular myocytes

options.label: B
options.text: Increasing sympathetic tone in systemic arteries

options.label: C
options.text: Decreasing the firing rate of carotid baroreceptors

questions.correct_answer: D. Slowing conduction in AV node
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Slowing conduction in AV node

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Carotid massage stimulates baroreceptors , which increases vagal tone , leading to slowed AV nodal conduction . This is useful in terminating AV nodal reentrant tachycardia (AVNRT) and restoring normal sinus rhythm.
  • ➤ stimulates baroreceptors
  • ➤ vagal tone
  • ➤ slowed AV nodal conduction
  • ➤ AV nodal reentrant tachycardia (AVNRT)

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the physician with significantly enlarged thyroid gland. Serum T3/T4 levels are decreased. lodine deficiency is suspected. Which of the following is the function of thyroid peroxidase in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Oxidation of iodide

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Thyroid peroxidase (TPO) catalyzes the oxidation of iodide (I⁻ to I₂) , iodination of tyrosine residues , and coupling of iodotyrosines in thyroid hormone synthesis.
  • ➤ oxidation of iodide (I⁻ to I₂)
  • ➤ iodination of tyrosine residues
  • ➤ coupling of iodotyrosines

questions.text: A healthy, 25-year-old medical student participates in a 20-kilometer charity run for the Indian Medical Association. Which muscles does the student use (contract) during expiration while running?
questions.correct_answer: C. Internal intercostals and abdominal recti
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Internal intercostals and abdominal recti

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Forced expiration during exercise is an active process that involves internal intercostals and abdominal muscles , which work together to expel air forcefully from the lungs.
  • ➤ Forced expiration during exercise
  • ➤ active
  • ➤ internal intercostals
  • ➤ abdominal muscles
  • ➤ expel air forcefully

questions.text: While analyzing the impact of acute blood loss on cardiac function by interpreting changes in the Frank Starling curves. Understanding how various clinical interventions or pathophysiological states affect stroke volume is vital. Given the patient's condition of mild hemorrhage and the associated compensatory mechanisms, to which point will the stroke volume shift from point X on the graph?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Point A

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mild hemorrhage activates RAAS, increasing angiotensin II and venoconstriction, which improves venous return and shifts the Frank-Starling position along the same curve, increasing cardiac output.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with progressive muscle weakness and difficulty walking. He was recently diagnosed with poliomyelitis, which has affected his motor neurons. Upon investigation, a biopsy of his nerve cells reveals impaired axonal transport. Which of the following pairs correctly identifies the motor proteins involved in anterograde and retrograde axonal transport, respectively, in the affected neurons?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Kinesin and dynein

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Kinesin mediates anterograde transport (soma → axon terminal) to deliver essential cellular components. Dynein mediates retrograde transport (axon terminal → soma) to recycle materials and transport pathogens like polio, rabies, and tetanus toxin back to the CNS.
  • ➤ Kinesin mediates anterograde transport (soma → axon terminal) to deliver essential cellular components.
  • ➤ Kinesin mediates anterograde transport (soma → axon terminal)
  • ➤ Dynein mediates retrograde transport (axon terminal → soma) to recycle materials and transport pathogens like polio, rabies, and tetanus toxin back to the CNS.
  • ➤ Dynein mediates retrograde transport (axon terminal → soma)
  • ➤ polio, rabies, and tetanus toxin

questions.text: Which of the following is the incorrect match?

options.label: A
options.text: Gastrin from G cells from stomach

options.label: B
options.text: GIP from L cells from duodenum and jejunum

options.label: C
options.text: Secretin from S cells of duodenum and jejunum

options.label: D
options.text: CCK from I cell of duodenum and pancreas

questions.correct_answer: B. GIP from L cells from duodenum and jejunum
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) GIP from L cells from duodenum and jejunum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ GIP is secreted by K cells (not L cells) and stimulates insulin release . L cells secrete GLP-1, an incretin hormone that enhances insulin secretion . I cells release CCK, which promotes gallbladder contraction and pancreatic enzyme secretion but are not found in the pancreas .
  • ➤ GIP is secreted by K cells (not L cells) and stimulates insulin release .
  • ➤ GIP is secreted by K cells (not L cells)
  • ➤ stimulates insulin release
  • ➤ L cells secrete GLP-1, an incretin hormone that enhances insulin secretion .
  • ➤ L cells secrete GLP-1, an incretin hormone that enhances insulin secretion
  • ➤ I cells release CCK, which promotes gallbladder contraction and pancreatic enzyme secretion but are not found in the pancreas .
  • ➤ I cells release CCK, which promotes gallbladder contraction and pancreatic enzyme secretion
  • ➤ not found in the pancreas

questions.text: The tact lie discrimination will be affected in the lesion of this ascending sensory pathway of the spinal cord?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Posterior column

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tactile (two-point) discrimination is mediated by the Posterior Column-Medial Lemniscus Pathway , which is responsible for fine touch, proprioception, and vibration . Lesions in this pathway impair sensory discrimination and proprioception .
  • ➤ Posterior Column-Medial Lemniscus Pathway
  • ➤ fine touch, proprioception, and vibration
  • ➤ sensory discrimination and proprioception

questions.text: In the cardiac muscle, the inhibition of Na+ K+ ATPase results in?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Depolarisation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Inhibition of Na⁺/K⁺ ATPase in cardiac muscle results in depolarization due to accumulation of intracellular Na⁺ and reduced K⁺ influx , leading to increased excitability of the cardiac cells.
  • ➤ Na⁺/K⁺ ATPase
  • ➤ depolarization
  • ➤ accumulation of intracellular Na⁺ and reduced K⁺ influx
  • ➤ increased excitability

questions.text: A 30-year-old male had headache, palpitations and difficulty in breathing during his mountain trekking (climbing). His SPO 2 was found to be decreased (<80%) leading to clinical features of acute mountain sickness. Which of the following nerve fibers are most susceptible to these hypoxic changes?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) B fibers

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ B fibers (small myelinated autonomic fibers) are the most susceptible to hypoxia and are affected in conditions like acute mountain sickness , leading to autonomic dysfunction such as tachycardia, dyspnea, and vascular instability .
  • ➤ B fibers (small myelinated autonomic fibers) are the most susceptible to hypoxia
  • ➤ acute mountain sickness
  • ➤ tachycardia, dyspnea, and vascular instability

questions.text: Which of the following does this graph signify?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Bronchitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ FEV₁/FVC <70% suggests an obstructive lung disease (e.g., bronchitis, emphysema, asthma). FEV₁/FVC ≥80% suggests a restrictive lung disease (e.g., fibrosis, interstitial lung disease). This graph strongly suggests chronic bronchitis , a type of COPD , due to the severely reduced FEV₁/FVC ratio (47%).
  • ➤ FEV₁/FVC <70% suggests an obstructive lung disease (e.g., bronchitis, emphysema, asthma).
  • ➤ FEV₁/FVC <70% suggests an obstructive lung disease (e.g., bronchitis, emphysema, asthma).
  • ➤ FEV₁/FVC ≥80% suggests a restrictive lung disease (e.g., fibrosis, interstitial lung disease).
  • ➤ FEV₁/FVC ≥80% suggests a restrictive lung disease (e.g., fibrosis, interstitial lung disease).
  • ➤ This graph strongly suggests chronic bronchitis , a type of COPD , due to the severely reduced FEV₁/FVC ratio (47%).
  • ➤ strongly suggests chronic bronchitis
  • ➤ COPD
  • ➤ severely reduced FEV₁/FVC ratio

questions.text: A 30-year-old mountaineer presents to the clinic after returning from a high-altitude expedition. He reports experiencing fatigue and shortness of breath while at high altitudes. Which of the following is least likely to be observed in this individual as a physiological adaptation to high altitude?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hypoventilation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ At high altitude , the body compensates for hypoxia by hyperventilation , polycythemia , increased hemoglobin levels , and higher myoglobin concentrations . Hypoventilation is least likely , as it would worsen oxygen deprivation rather than improving it.
  • ➤ high altitude
  • ➤ hypoxia
  • ➤ hyperventilation
  • ➤ polycythemia
  • ➤ increased hemoglobin levels
  • ➤ higher myoglobin concentrations
  • ➤ Hypoventilation is least likely

questions.text: Identify the hormones A & B giving negative feedback on Hypothalamus - Pituitary axis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Inhibin & Testosterone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the male Hypothalamus-Pituitary-Gonadal (HPG) axis) , Testosterone (from Leydig cells) inhibits GnRH and LH , while Inhibin (from Sertoli cells) inhibits FSH to regulate spermatogenesis and hormonal balance.
  • ➤ male Hypothalamus-Pituitary-Gonadal (HPG) axis)
  • ➤ Testosterone (from Leydig cells)
  • ➤ GnRH and LH
  • ➤ Inhibin (from Sertoli cells)
  • ➤ FSH

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with symptoms of severe hypertension and is suspected to have a renal origin for her condition. Imaging studies and kidney biopsy reveal abnormalities localized to the medulla of the kidney. Which of the following structures is least likely to be involved, given its primary location is outside the medulla?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Juxtaglomerular apparatus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Juxtaglomerular Apparatus (JGA) is located in the renal cortex and is responsible for renin secretion and blood pressure regulation .
  • ➤ Juxtaglomerular Apparatus (JGA) is located in the renal cortex
  • ➤ renin secretion and blood pressure regulation

questions.text: The rate of diffusion of a substance is plotted against concentration gradient in the following graph. The substance is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Glucose

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Facilitated diffusion of glucose occurs via carrier proteins (GLUT transporters) and follows saturation kinetics, unlike simple diffusion.

questions.text: In the following LV pressure-volume loop diagram, point C denotes:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Aortic valve opens

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The aortic valve closes at the end of ventricular systole, marking the start of isovolumetric relaxation in the left ventricle.
  • ➤ The aortic valve closes at the end of ventricular systole, marking the start of isovolumetric relaxation in the left ventricle.

questions.text: One transport system across the cell membrane is given below. The process indicates which of the following:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Simple diffusion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Simple diffusion is a passive transport mechanism in which molecules move from a high concentration to a low concentration across the cell membrane without the need for carrier proteins or ATP.

questions.text: MRI of the brain shows a lesion in the left precentral gyrus. Damage to which of the following functions is most likely responsible for his symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Voluntary movement

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The precentral gyrus (primary motor cortex) is responsible for voluntary movement. Damage to this area leads to motor deficits, typically on the contralateral side of the body.

questions.text: The following diagram is from adrenal gland. Hormone produced by the marked area A in the following image is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Aldosterone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The zona glomerulosa of the adrenal cortex produces aldosterone, a mineralocorticoid that regulates sodium and potassium balance, contributing to blood pressure control.
  • ➤ The zona glomerulosa of the adrenal cortex produces aldosterone, a mineralocorticoid that regulates sodium and potassium balance, contributing to blood pressure control.

questions.text: In the following diagram, the curve "X" represents the normal relationship of alveolar ventilation with PaCO2, when PaO2 is 100mmHg. If pH changed from 7.4 to 7.3, change in alveolar ventilation will shift to which of the curve?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Curve C

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A decrease in pH (acidosis) leads to an increase in alveolar ventilation to remove CO₂. The ventilatory response shifts to a curve that is parallel to the normal but at a higher ventilation rate, which in this case is represented by Curve D.

questions.text: Best index for afterload?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) MAP

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mean Arterial Pressure (MAP) is the best index for afterload because it represents the pressure the heart must overcome to eject blood. Total Peripheral Resistance (TPR) determines afterload but is not directly measurable in clinical practice.

questions.text: Human genome has max genes for which of the following:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Odorant receptors

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Odorant receptor genes form the largest gene family in the human genome, with approximately 1000 genes dedicated to detecting and distinguishing different smells.

questions.text: Negative ion concentration is 100mMol/L outside the cell membrane and 10mMol/L inside cell membrane. Nernst potential of this ion:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) -61

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Nernst potential is calculated using the equation E =
  • ➤ (61/z) log 10 ([Ion] outside / [Ion] inside ). For a negatively charged ion with an
  • ➤ extracellular concentration of 100 mMol/L and an intracellular concentration of 10 mMol/L, the equilibrium potential is -61 mV.

questions.text: Anatomical dead space is measured with:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Single breath nitrogen test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Anatomical dead space is best measured using the Single Breath Nitrogen Test (Fowler’s Method), which evaluates the washout of nitrogen during a controlled exhalation.

questions.text: The following is a recording of static pressure volume curve of lungs, from different patients. What does the “B” curve represent?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Interstitial fibrosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A downward-shifted pressure-volume curve indicates decreased lung compliance, characteristic of restrictive lung diseases like interstitial fibrosis. In contrast, emphysema increases lung compliance, shifting the curve upward.
  • ➤ A downward-shifted pressure-volume curve indicates decreased lung compliance, characteristic of restrictive lung diseases like interstitial fibrosis. In contrast, emphysema increases lung compliance, shifting the curve upward.

questions.text: Na-I transporter is present in all except?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pituitary

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The sodium-iodide symporter (NIS) is responsible for iodide uptake in the thyroid, salivary glands, placenta, and mammary glands but is absent in the pituitary gland.

questions.text: Feed forward control system is employed during the regulation of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Temperature

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Feed-forward control is used in temperature regulation, where the body anticipates changes and initiates responses before a significant deviation in core temperature occurs. Other physiological parameters like blood volume, pH, and blood pressure rely on feedback mechanisms.

questions.text: Maximum area in homunculus signifies which one of the following?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Increased preciseness of movements

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The areas with maximum representation in the motor homunculus correspond to parts of the body that require precise, fine motor control, such as the hands, lips, and tongue. The size of the representation depends on the degree of motor control, not the number of muscle fibers.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with neurodegenerative disease experiences muscle weakness and difficulty walking. The condition is linked to impaired axonal transport, leading to neuronal dysfunction. Considering the patient's symptoms and the critical role of cellular components, which function is not primarily associated with microtubules?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) None of the above

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Microtubules are essential for spindle formation, intracellular cargo transport, and mitosis. Their dysfunction is associated with neurodegenerative diseases, where impaired axonal transport leads to neuronal degeneration.

questions.text: The intrapleural pressure will be A 40-year-old healthy male participates in a study at a respiratory physiology lab. The researchers are measuring various respiratory parameters, including intrapleural pressure, to better understand the mechanics of breathing. One of the researchers asks the students to identify the normal intrapleural pressure at the base of the lungs during the start of inspiration in a healthy adult. What would be the answer?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) – 2.5 mm Hg

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ At the start of inspiration, the intrapleural pressure at the base of the lung is approximately –2.5 mm Hg. This negative pressure helps maintain lung expansion and facilitates airflow into the lungs during inspiration.

questions.text: During a medical simulation exercise, a patient presents with respiratory distress. The medical team is discussing the various pressures involved in the respiratory system. Which of the following statements accurately describes the relationship between the different pressures in the pulmonary circulation for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Intrapleural pressure is always greater than intrapulmonary pressure (IPP) during inspiration.

options.label: B
options.text: Transpulmonary pressure (TPP) is the difference between intrapleural pressure (ITP) and Intrapulmonary pressure.

options.label: C
options.text: Intrapulmonary pressure (IPP) is always higher than atmospheric pressure.

options.label: D
options.text: Trans-respiratory pressure is the difference between intrapleural pressure (ITP) and transpulmonary pressure (TPP).

questions.correct_answer: B. Transpulmonary pressure (TPP) is the difference between intrapleural pressure (ITP) and Intrapulmonary pressure.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Transpulmonary pressure (TPP) is the difference between intrapleural pressure (ITP) and Intrapulmonary pressure.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Transpulmonary pressure (TPP) is the key pressure maintaining lung inflation and is calculated as the difference between intrapulmonary (alveolar) pressure and intrapleural pressure. Intrapleural pressure is always negative and lower than intrapulmonary pressure during the respiratory cycle.

questions.text: During a medical physiology lecture, the professor discusses the concept of A-V (arterial-venous) oxygen difference and its variations in different types of hypoxia. The students are asked to identify the type of hypoxia in which the least A-V oxygen difference is observed.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Histotoxic hypoxia.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Histotoxic hypoxia shows the least A-V oxygen difference because tissues fail to utilize oxygen efficiently, leading to high venous oxygen levels. In contrast, stagnant hypoxia increases A-V oxygen difference due to reduced blood flow and increased oxygen extraction by tissues.

questions.text: In a respiratory physiology seminar, the instructor discusses the mechanisms that prevent hyperinflation of the lungs during the breathing cycle. The students are asked to identify the specific reflex that plays a role in preventing lung hyperinflation:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hering Breuer reflex.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Hering-Breuer reflex prevents excessive lung inflation by activating pulmonary stretch receptors that inhibit further inspiration, ensuring controlled tidal volume and respiratory rhythm.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presents with sensory disturbances in the lower limbs and is being evaluated for potential neurological involvement. The physician suspects a lesion affecting the posterior column of the spinal cord. In the context of this patient's symptoms, which of the following complaint is likely to be incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: The patient reports a complete loss of vibration sensation in the lower limbs.

options.label: B
options.text: The patient complains of an inability to perceive pressure sensations on the feet.

options.label: C
options.text: The patient describes altered temperature perception in the lower limbs.

options.label: D
options.text: The patient experiences difficulty in sensing joint positions and movements (proprioception) in the legs.

questions.correct_answer: C. The patient describes altered temperature perception in the lower limbs.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) The patient describes altered temperature perception in the lower limbs.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The posterior column of the spinal cord is responsible for proprioception, vibration, pressure, and fine touch sensations. Temperature and pain sensations are carried by the lateral spinothalamic tract. A lesion in the posterior column does not affect temperature perception.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with specific sensory deficits, particularly in the detection of low-frequency vibrations and fine textural variations upon tactile examination. To elucidate the underlying pathology of his sensory impairment, the attending neurologist must determine which cutaneous receptors, known for their specialization in tactile sensation, are likely compromised:

options.label: A
options.text: Merkel cells, responsible for the perception of sustained pressure and temperature.

options.label: B
options.text: Meissner corpuscles, specialized for detecting light touch and low-frequency vibrations.

options.label: C
options.text: Pacinian corpuscles, slowly adapting for sensing low-frequency vibrations.

options.label: D
options.text: Ruffini end bulbs, involved in the detection of two point discrimination.

questions.correct_answer: B. Meissner corpuscles, specialized for detecting light touch and low-frequency vibrations.
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Meissner corpuscles are responsible for detecting light touch and low-frequency vibrations. Damage to these receptors leads to impaired fine texture discrimination and reduced sensitivity to low-frequency vibrations. Pacinian corpuscles detect high-frequency vibrations, while Merkel cells and Ruffini endings have different tactile functions.
